subject: Design
subcategory: Design Disasters and What They Teach Us
title: The Ford Pinto: The Cost of a Human Life
description: A quick, practical guide to The Ford Pinto: The Cost of a Human Life.

hook.text: Ford knew the Pinto's fuel tank could explode in rear collisions. They calculated fixing it wasn't worth it.

buildup.text: The Pinto's fuel tank sat between the rear axle and bumper ‚Äî vulnerable to even low-speed rear impacts.

discovery.text: Ford's internal memo valued a human life at $200,000 and concluded the $11-per-car fix wasn't cost-effective.

twist.text: When the memo leaked, public outrage forced a recall of 1.5 million vehicles. Ethics, not engineering, was the failure.

climax.text: The Pinto case established that cost-benefit analysis cannot override human safety in product design.

punchline.text: When you calculate the price of a life, you've already failed at design.

quiz.question: Why didn't Ford initially fix the Pinto's fuel tank?
options: They didn't know about the problem
They calculated lawsuits would cost less than the $11-per-car fix
